awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Impact of microbial and termite communities on transfer of decaying wood to stable and protected mineral soil carbon pools
awd_abstract_narration:
As forests age, the death of trees adds dead wood to the forest floor.  Even in younger forests, strong wind events, insect outbreaks, fire and forest management all can result in accumulation of dead wood.  Dead wood stores carbon, but how much in the long-term is uncertain.  Much of the carbon in wood is slowly returned to the atmosphere as CO2 during decomposition. Some, however, also enters the soil, where it can be stored for decades to centuries.  In 2011, pine, aspen and birch logs were placed in nine forests across the U.S. to help determine how factors such as climate, wood type, presence of termites and fungi affect wood decomposition rate.  The wood used had a unique carbon isotopic signature that allows the research team to trace it as it enters the soil, and to measure how fast carbon is either lost to decomposition or stored as soil carbon. This knowledge will improve understanding of carbon cycling in forests and allow better prediction of how a changing climate or increased tree death from forest disturbance could alter carbon storage in forests. This research will help to determine if forests will be carbon sinks or sources for atmospheric CO2 over long time scales. The project will also give middle and high school students a chance to experience scientific research first-hand, and increase awareness of STEM topics in rural schools near four of the research sites. Project scientists will work with teachers to involve students in research-based discovery and analysis at a nearby field site and incorporate project topics related to ecology and soil science in school curricula, providing a foundation for increasing student interest in science and engineering careers.

The fungal and invertebrate communities that dominate wood decomposition have distinct lignin and carbohydrate decomposition pathways along a white- to brown-rot continuum, and these alter the amount of carbon diverted to the mineral soil.  This study's specific objectives are to assess the role of different fungal/bacterial communities and termites on lignin- and carbohydrate-decay pathways for the three wood types and determine how this affects wood carbon movement into labile and protected mineral soil carbon pools. This entails: 1) using the 13C signature of labelled wood to assess the role of decomposer community function on wood-decay pathways, mass loss, and wood carbon movement into mineral soil; and 2) using a unique series of termite-exclusion plots to determine the effect of termite activity on fungal wood-decay community composition, wood-decay pathways, and incorporation of wood carbon into the mineral soil.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The importance of dead wood to the ecology of forests is well recognized, as it comprises nearly 20% of forest biomass. Dead wood is considered a potentially important terrestrial carbon sink due to its relatively slow decomposition rate, but as wood decays over time, much of the carbon it contains is returned to the atmosphere as carbon dioxide. Still, some carbon is also transferred to soil, where it may remain stable for long periods of time. Thus, understanding the extent of incorporation of wood carbon into soil carbon pools during decomposition is important to managers, policy analysts, and modelers when assessing potential effects of climate change or forest management practices on ecosystem carbon storage and sequestration. Unfortunately, the carbon from decomposing wood normally cannot be differentiated from other soil carbon using standard soil analyses.

Researchers from Michigan Technological University, the USDA Forest Service, the University of Georgia and the University of Minnesota solved this problem by using the depleted 13C isotopic signature in wood from loblolly pine, trembling aspen and paper birch trees grown for over a decade at Free Air CO2 Enrichment (FACE) experiments. The unique isotopic signature carbon from the decomposing wood to be tracked into soil carbon pools.  

In 2011, logs from the final harvests of several FACE studies were placed in nine diverse forests across the US, creating the FACE Wood Decomposition Experiment (FWDE, Figure 1). With support from the National Science Foundation, the research team examined soil and forest floor collected beneath and near the decomposing logs after ten years of decomposition (Figure 2) to determine movement of wood carbon into soil and forest floor and factors affecting the rate of movement and location of wood carbon in soil. 

Significant amounts of wood carbon moved into the soil and forest floor as dead wood decomposition proceeded. After ten years, an average of 6% of the logs’ original carbon resided in forest floor and soil, which represented about 1/9th of log mass loss to that date.  An average of 40% of the log’s carbon content remained in the decomposing logs, and up to 54% had returned to the atmosphere as carbon dioxide, but values varied greatly by site and wood species (Figure 3). 

Birch logs decayed faster and had the greatest amount of wood carbon moving to the soil after ten years.  Aspen had intermediate movement of wood carbon into soil pools, and pine had the lowest (Figure 4). Decomposition proceeded faster at warm, moist sites in the southeast US, where birch and aspen logs were essentially gone after ten years, but was slower at sites that were very cold or very dry.  The rate of movement of wood C into forest floor and soil generally corresponded to decay rate. 

Most of the wood carbon found in soil after ten years of decomposition was in either the forest floor and surface 10 cm or the deepest soil layer examined (30-50 cm) (Figure 4). Deep soil wood carbon was almost entirely in the heavy fraction (HF), which is carbon adsorbed by clay-sized soil particles.  Carbon in the surface soil that came from the wood above was mostly in the light fraction (LF), which essentially is small wood particles.  These results, combined with the low levels of wood carbon found at intermediate depths (10-20 and 20-30 cm, Figure 4), are consistent with movement of wood carbon as dissolved organic carbon from the surface to lower soil depths, where a portion of the dissolved carbon comes out of solution and adheres to mineral particles, becoming HF carbon.  As the wood carbon moved into soil, significant lateral spreading occurred, with much wood carbon found at 30 and 50 cm horizontal distances from the log (Figure 4).

An examination of fungi involved in the decomposition process showed that white rot dominated the decay process, with no brown rot occurring for birch at any site, and brown rot occurring in only 21% of aspen and pine logs.  In brown rot, lignin largely remains in the residual wood, while in white rot, all components of the wood are decomposed. This finding is consistent with the large amounts of HF carbon at depth at most sites and greater amounts of log C being found at depth under decaying birch logs. 

This NSF project helped support the doctoral research of three students, introduced twenty-three undergraduate students to the research process through their involvement in both field and lab activities, and was used to introduce middle-school students near one of the sites to decomposition processes, ecosystem carbon cycling, and their role in the global carbon cycle.  In addition, project data aided the development of the Forest-DNDC model and has given insights into how management activities or natural events that alter dead wood creation in forests might in turn alter the amount of carbon sequestered in soils.
